TextEquiv.Unicode: Christ goe about earnestly to sever
hypocrisie from love. For Paul saith,
Let not your love be feyned. Againe,
The ende of the commaundement is
love of a pure heart, and a good con
science, and faith not fained. On the
other side, John cryeth out saying :
Ay babes let us not love in worde nor
in tongue, but in deede and in veritie.
Moreover, in this sinceritie wee con
teine a free willing and merie cheare
fulnesse that nothing may seeme to be
done unwillingly or by copulsion. For
Paule saith: Let everie man doe with
a good purpose of minde, not of tron
ble or necessitie. For God reduireth a
chearefull giver.
Secondarily, it is to be looked for of
us that we should love our neighbour
as our selves. For the Lorde hath
sayde, Love thy neighbour as thy selfe:
that is, most intirely ad as dearely
as by any meanes thou mayest. For
there is not anie affection that is of
more force or vehemencie than selfe
love is. Neither was it the Lorde his
minde that the love of our neighbour
should be any whit lesser than the love
that we beare to our selves: but ra
ther by this he gave us to understande
that we ought to bestowe on others
as ardent love as may be, to wit, the
verie same affection that wee beare to
our selves and our owne estate, and
that we ought to be readie to doe good
to other, or to keepe them from harme
with the same care, faith, and dili
gence, with the same zeale & goodwill,
wherewith we provide for our selves
or our owne safetie. Whereupon the
Lorde in another place sayth: what
soever thou wouldest have doone to
thy selfe, that doe thou to an other
And what so ever thou wouldest not
have done to thy selfe, do not thou the
same to another. A

Christ goe about earnestly to sever hypocrisie from love. For Paul saith, Let not your love be feyned. Againe, The ende of the commaundement is love of a pure heart, and a good con science, and faith not fained. On the other side, John cryeth out saying : Ay babes let us not love in worde nor in tongue, but in deede and in veritie. Moreover, in this sinceritie wee con teine a free willing and merie cheare fulnesse that nothing may seeme to be done unwillingly or by copulsion. For Paule saith: Let everie man doe with a good purpose of minde, not of tron ble or necessitie. For God reduireth a chearefull giver. Secondarily, it is to be looked for of us that we should love our neighbour as our selves. For the Lorde hath sayde, Love thy neighbour as thy selfe: that is, most intirely ad as dearely as by any meanes thou mayest. For there is not anie affection that is of more force or vehemencie than selfe love is. Neither was it the Lorde his minde that the love of our neighbour should be any whit lesser than the love that we beare to our selves: but ra ther by this he gave us to understande that we ought to bestowe on others as ardent love as may be, to wit, the verie same affection that wee beare to our selves and our owne estate, and that we ought to be readie to doe good to other, or to keepe them from harme with the same care, faith, and dili gence, with the same zeale & goodwill, wherewith we provide for our selves or our owne safetie. Whereupon the Lorde in another place sayth: what soever thou wouldest have doone to thy selfe, that doe thou to an other And what so ever thou wouldest not have done to thy selfe, do not thou the same to another. A
Lord require two things at our hands,
not to hurt, & to doe good. For it is not
enough not to hurt a ma, but also to do
him good, so much as lyeth in us to do
For we our selves desire not onely to
keepe our selves from hurt, but to doe
our selves good also,
But if so it be (dearely beloved) that
ye doe not yet sufficiently understand
the manner howe we ought to love
our neighbour, then marke (I beseech
you) the thirde part of my description
of this love, where I saide, That we
ought to love our neighbor with that
same love wherewith the Lord Christ
loved us. For in the Gospell after S.
John the Lord sayth: This is my com
maundement that yee love one ano
ther, as I have loved you. So then here
ye have the manner of our love, wee
must love our neighbours as Christ
hath loved us. But in what fort hath
Christ loved us: Here againe in the
Gospell he sayth: No man hath grea
ter love then this that a man bestowe
his life for his friende. So then, such
must the manner of our love towarde
our neighbour be, as that we shall not
doubt to give our life for our neigh
bour. And if so it be then, that for our
neighbours fake wee owe the losse of
our life there is nothing verily that
we owe him not, considering that to
a man nothing is more deare than life,
For sooner will hee loose all that hee
hath than once to put his life in leoper
die. Whereupon the Apostle John cry
ethout, and sayeth: Hereby perceive
wee love, because he laide downe his
life for us: and we ouwthe tostay downe
our lives for the brethren. This is
easie to be understoode by reason of the
most evident erample. Let us praye
earnestlie and continuallie to the
Lorde that we may indeede fulsill the
thing that we doe ma

Lord require two things at our hands, not to hurt, & to doe good. For it is not enough not to hurt a ma, but also to do him good, so much as lyeth in us to do For we our selves desire not onely to keepe our selves from hurt, but to doe our selves good also, But if so it be (dearely beloved) that ye doe not yet sufficiently understand the manner howe we ought to love our neighbour, then marke (I beseech you) the thirde part of my description of this love, where I saide, That we ought to love our neighbor with that same love wherewith the Lord Christ loved us. For in the Gospell after S. John the Lord sayth: This is my com maundement that yee love one ano ther, as I have loved you. So then here ye have the manner of our love, wee must love our neighbours as Christ hath loved us. But in what fort hath Christ loved us: Here againe in the Gospell he sayth: No man hath grea ter love then this that a man bestowe his life for his friende. So then, such must the manner of our love towarde our neighbour be, as that we shall not doubt to give our life for our neigh bour. And if so it be then, that for our neighbours fake wee owe the losse of our life there is nothing verily that we owe him not, considering that to a man nothing is more deare than life, For sooner will hee loose all that hee hath than once to put his life in leoper die. Whereupon the Apostle John cry ethout, and sayeth: Hereby perceive wee love, because he laide downe his life for us: and we ouwthe tostay downe our lives for the brethren. This is easie to be understoode by reason of the most evident erample. Let us praye earnestlie and continuallie to the Lorde that we may indeede fulsill the thing that we doe ma
